trans-unit.source: Deploy an ASP.NET MVC 5 mobile web app in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Deploy an ASP.NET MVC 5 mobile web app in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: A tutorial that teaches you how to deploy a web app to Azure App Service using mobile features in ASP.NET MVC 5 web application.
trans-unit.target: A tutorial that teaches you how to deploy a web app to Azure App Service using mobile features in ASP.NET MVC 5 web application.

trans-unit.source: Deploy an ASP.NET MVC 5 mobile web app in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Deploy an ASP.NET MVC 5 mobile web app in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: This tutorial will teach you the basics of how to build an ASP.NET MVC 5
trans-unit.target: This tutorial will teach you the basics of how to build an ASP.NET MVC 5

trans-unit.source: web app that is mobile-friendly and deploy it to Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: web app that is mobile-friendly and deploy it to Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial, you need
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, you need

trans-unit.source: [Visual Studio Express 2013 for Web][Visual Studio Express 2013]
trans-unit.target: [Visual Studio Express 2013 for Web][Visual Studio Express 2013]

trans-unit.source: or the professional edition of Visual Studio if you already
trans-unit.target: or the professional edition of Visual Studio if you already

trans-unit.source: have that.
trans-unit.target: have that.

trans-unit.source: You can use [Visual Studio 2015] but the screen shots will be different and you must use the ASP.NET 4.x templates.
trans-unit.target: You can use [Visual Studio 2015] but the screen shots will be different and you must use the ASP.NET 4.x templates.

trans-unit.target: What You'll Build

trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, you'll add mobile features to the simple

trans-unit.target: conference-listing application that's provided in the [starter project][StarterProject].

trans-unit.target: Here's what you'll learn:

trans-unit.source: How to use Visual Studio 2013 to publish your web application directly to a web app in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: How to use Visual Studio 2013 to publish your web application directly to a web app in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: Set up the development environment
trans-unit.target: Set up the development environment

trans-unit.source: Set up your development environment by installing the Azure SDK for .NET 2.5.1 or later.
trans-unit.target: Set up your development environment by installing the Azure SDK for .NET 2.5.1 or later.

trans-unit.source: To install the Azure SDK for .NET, click the link below.
trans-unit.target: To install the Azure SDK for .NET, click the link below.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have Visual Studio 2013 installed yet, it will be installed by the link.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have Visual Studio 2013 installed yet, it will be installed by the link.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial requires Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial requires Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: [Azure SDK for Visual Studio 2013][AzureSDKVs2013]
trans-unit.target: [Azure SDK for Visual Studio 2013][AzureSDKVs2013]

trans-unit.source: In the Web Platform Installer window, click **Install** and proceed with the installation.
trans-unit.target: In the Web Platform Installer window, click **Install** and proceed with the installation.

trans-unit.source: You will also need a mobile browser emulator.
trans-unit.target: You will also need a mobile browser emulator.

trans-unit.source: Any of the following will
trans-unit.target: Any of the following will

trans-unit.source: work:
trans-unit.target: work:

trans-unit.source: Browser Emulator in [Internet Explorer 11 F12 developer tools][EmulatorIE11] (used in all mobile
trans-unit.target: Browser Emulator in [Internet Explorer 11 F12 developer tools][EmulatorIE11] (used in all mobile

trans-unit.source: browser screenshots).
trans-unit.target: browser screenshots).

trans-unit.source: It has user agent string presets for Windows Phone 8, Windows Phone 7, and Apple iPad.
trans-unit.target: It has user agent string presets for Windows Phone 8, Windows Phone 7, and Apple iPad.

trans-unit.source: Browser Emulator in [Google Chrome DevTools][EmulatorChrome].
trans-unit.target: Browser Emulator in [Google Chrome DevTools][EmulatorChrome].

trans-unit.source: It contains presets for numerous Android devices, as well as Apple iPhone, Apple iPad, and Amazon Kindle Fire.
trans-unit.target: It contains presets for numerous Android devices, as well as Apple iPhone, Apple iPad, and Amazon Kindle Fire.

trans-unit.source: It also emulates touch events.
trans-unit.target: It also emulates touch events.

trans-unit.target: Opera Mobile Emulator

trans-unit.source: Deploy the starter project to an Azure web app
trans-unit.target: Deploy the starter project to an Azure web app

trans-unit.source: Download the conference-listing application [starter project][StarterProject].
trans-unit.target: Download the conference-listing application [starter project][StarterProject].

trans-unit.source: Then in Windows Explorer, right-click the Mvc5Mobile.zip file and choose *Properties*.
trans-unit.target: Then in Windows Explorer, right-click the Mvc5Mobile.zip file and choose *Properties*.

trans-unit.source: In the **Mvc5Mobile.zip Properties** dialog box,
trans-unit.target: In the **Mvc5Mobile.zip Properties** dialog box,

trans-unit.source: choose the **Unblock** button.
trans-unit.target: choose the **Unblock** button.

trans-unit.source: (Unblocking prevents a security warning
trans-unit.target: (Unblocking prevents a security warning

trans-unit.source: that occurs when you try to use a *.zip* file that you've downloaded
trans-unit.target: that occurs when you try to use a *.zip* file that you've downloaded

trans-unit.source: from the web.)
trans-unit.target: from the web.)

trans-unit.source: Right-click the *Mvc5Mobile.zip* file and select **Extract All** to
trans-unit.target: Right-click the *Mvc5Mobile.zip* file and select **Extract All** to

trans-unit.source: unzip the file.
trans-unit.target: unzip the file.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open the *Mvc5Mobile.sln* file.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open the *Mvc5Mobile.sln* file.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and click **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and click **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: ![][DeployClickPublish]
trans-unit.target: ![][DeployClickPublish]

trans-unit.source: In Publish Web, click **Microsoft Azure Web Apps**.
trans-unit.target: In Publish Web, click **Microsoft Azure Web Apps**.

trans-unit.source: ![][DeployClickWebSites]
trans-unit.target: ![][DeployClickWebSites]

trans-unit.source: Click **Sign in**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Sign in**.

trans-unit.source: ![][DeploySignIn]
trans-unit.target: ![][DeploySignIn]

trans-unit.source: Follow the prompts to log into your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: Follow the prompts to log into your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: The Select Existing Web App dialog should now show you as signed in.
trans-unit.target: The Select Existing Web App dialog should now show you as signed in.

trans-unit.source: Click **New**.
trans-unit.target: Click **New**.

trans-unit.source: ![][DeployNewWebsite]
trans-unit.target: ![][DeployNewWebsite]

trans-unit.source: In the **Web App name** field, specify a unique app name prefix.
trans-unit.target: In the **Web App name** field, specify a unique app name prefix.

trans-unit.source: Your fully-qualified web app name will be *<prefix>*.azurewebsites.net.
trans-unit.target: Your fully-qualified web app name will be *<prefix>*.azurewebsites.net.

trans-unit.source: Also, configure the **App Service plan**, **Resource group**, and **Region** fields.
trans-unit.target: Also, configure the **App Service plan**, **Resource group**, and **Region** fields.

trans-unit.source: Then, click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: Then, click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: ![][DeploySiteSettings]
trans-unit.target: ![][DeploySiteSettings]

trans-unit.source: The Publish Web dialog will be filled with the settings for your new web app.
trans-unit.target: The Publish Web dialog will be filled with the settings for your new web app.

trans-unit.source: Click **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: ![][DeployPublishSite]
trans-unit.target: ![][DeployPublishSite]

trans-unit.source: Once Visual Studio finishes publishing the starter project to the Azure web app, the desktop browser opens to display the live web app.
trans-unit.target: Once Visual Studio finishes publishing the starter project to the Azure web app, the desktop browser opens to display the live web app.

trans-unit.source: Start your mobile browser emulator, copy the URL for
trans-unit.target: Start your mobile browser emulator, copy the URL for

trans-unit.source: the conference application (*<prefix>*.azurewebsites.net) into the emulator, and then click the
trans-unit.target: the conference application (*<prefix>*.azurewebsites.net) into the emulator, and then click the

trans-unit.source: top-right button and select **Browse by tag**.
trans-unit.target: top-right button and select **Browse by tag**.

trans-unit.source: If you are using Internet
trans-unit.target: If you are using Internet

trans-unit.source: Explorer 11 as the default browser, you just need to type `F12`, then
trans-unit.target: Explorer 11 as the default browser, you just need to type `F12`, then

trans-unit.source: `Ctrl+8`, and then change the browser profile to **Windows Phone**.
trans-unit.target: `Ctrl+8`, and then change the browser profile to **Windows Phone**.

trans-unit.target: The

trans-unit.target: The ASP.NET tag view is zoom-fitted to the screen, which Bootstrap does

trans-unit.target: You have

trans-unit.target: already seen how it immediately improves the different views in your

trans-unit.target: For example, the navigation bar at the top is automatically

trans-unit.source: Bootstrap is not specific to ASP.NET MVC 5, and you can take advantage
trans-unit.target: Bootstrap is not specific to ASP.NET MVC 5, and you can take advantage

trans-unit.source: of these features in any web application.
trans-unit.target: of these features in any web application.

trans-unit.source: But it is now built into the
trans-unit.target: But it is now built into the

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET MVC 5 project template, so that your MVC 5 Web application can
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET MVC 5 project template, so that your MVC 5 Web application can

trans-unit.source: take advantage of Bootstrap by default.
trans-unit.target: take advantage of Bootstrap by default.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Bootstrap, go to the
trans-unit.target: For more information about Bootstrap, go to the

trans-unit.source: [Bootstrap][BootstrapSite] site.
trans-unit.target: [Bootstrap][BootstrapSite] site.

trans-unit.target: In the next section you'll see how to provide mobile-browser specific

trans-unit.target: Override the Views, Layouts, and Partial Views

trans-unit.source: You can override any view (including layouts and partial views) for
trans-unit.target: You can override any view (including layouts and partial views) for

trans-unit.target: mobile browsers in general, for an individual mobile browser, or for any

trans-unit.source: specific browser.
trans-unit.target: specific browser.

trans-unit.target: To provide a mobile-specific view, you can copy a view

trans-unit.target: For example, to create a mobile

trans-unit.target: *Index* view, you can copy *Views\\Home\\Index.cshtml* to

trans-unit.source: Create Browser-Specific Views
trans-unit.target: Create Browser-Specific Views

trans-unit.source: In addition to mobile-specific and desktop-specific views, you can
trans-unit.target: In addition to mobile-specific and desktop-specific views, you can

trans-unit.source: create views for an individual browser.
trans-unit.target: create views for an individual browser.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can create
trans-unit.target: For example, you can create

trans-unit.source: views that are specifically for the iPhone or the Android browser.
trans-unit.target: views that are specifically for the iPhone or the Android browser.

trans-unit.source: In this section,
trans-unit.target: In this section,

trans-unit.source: you'll create a layout for the iPhone browser and an iPhone version of
trans-unit.target: you'll create a layout for the iPhone browser and an iPhone version of

trans-unit.source: the *AllTags* view.
trans-unit.target: the *AllTags* view.

trans-unit.source: Open the *Global.asax* file and add the following code to the bottom of the
trans-unit.target: Open the *Global.asax* file and add the following code to the bottom of the

trans-unit.source: `Application_Start` method.
trans-unit.target: `Application_Start` method.

trans-unit.source: This code defines a new display mode named "iPhone" that will be matched
trans-unit.target: This code defines a new display mode named "iPhone" that will be matched

trans-unit.source: against each incoming request.
trans-unit.target: against each incoming request.

trans-unit.source: If the incoming request matches the
trans-unit.target: If the incoming request matches the

trans-unit.source: condition you defined (that is, if the user agent contains the string
trans-unit.target: condition you defined (that is, if the user agent contains the string

trans-unit.source: "iPhone"), ASP.NET MVC will look for views whose name contains the
trans-unit.target: "iPhone"), ASP.NET MVC will look for views whose name contains the

trans-unit.source: "iPhone" suffix.
trans-unit.target: "iPhone" suffix.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] When adding mobile browser-specific display modes, such as for iPhone and Android, be sure to set the first argument to `0` (insert at the top of the list) to make sure that the browser-specific mode takes precedence over the mobile template (*.Mobile.cshtml).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] When adding mobile browser-specific display modes, such as for iPhone and Android, be sure to set the first argument to `0` (insert at the top of the list) to make sure that the browser-specific mode takes precedence over the mobile template (*.Mobile.cshtml).

trans-unit.source: If the mobile template is at the top of the list instead, it will be selected over your intended display mode (the first match wins, and the mobile template matches all mobile browsers).
trans-unit.target: If the mobile template is at the top of the list instead, it will be selected over your intended display mode (the first match wins, and the mobile template matches all mobile browsers).

trans-unit.source: In the code, right-click `DefaultDisplayMode`, choose **Resolve**, and
trans-unit.target: In the code, right-click `DefaultDisplayMode`, choose **Resolve**, and

trans-unit.source: then choose `using System.Web.WebPages;`.
trans-unit.target: then choose `using System.Web.WebPages;`.

trans-unit.source: This adds a reference to the
trans-unit.target: This adds a reference to the

trans-unit.source: `System.Web.WebPages` namespace, which is where the
trans-unit.target: `System.Web.WebPages` namespace, which is where the

trans-unit.source: `DisplayModeProvider` and `DefaultDisplayMode` types are defined.
trans-unit.target: `DisplayModeProvider` and `DefaultDisplayMode` types are defined.

trans-unit.target: ![][ResolveDefaultDisplayMode]

trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can just manually add the following line to the

trans-unit.target: `using` section of the file.

trans-unit.target: Save the changes.

trans-unit.target: Copy the

trans-unit.source: You can globally disable a default (non-mobile) view from rendering
trans-unit.target: You can globally disable a default (non-mobile) view from rendering

trans-unit.source: inside a mobile layout by setting `RequireConsistentDisplayMode` to
trans-unit.target: inside a mobile layout by setting `RequireConsistentDisplayMode` to

trans-unit.source: `true` in the *Views\\\_ViewStart.cshtml* file, like this:
trans-unit.target: `true` in the *Views\\\_ViewStart.cshtml* file, like this:

trans-unit.source: When `RequireConsistentDisplayMode` is set to `true`, the mobile layout
trans-unit.target: When `RequireConsistentDisplayMode` is set to `true`, the mobile layout

trans-unit.source: (*\_Layout.Mobile.cshtml*) is used only for mobile views (i.e. when the
trans-unit.target: (*\_Layout.Mobile.cshtml*) is used only for mobile views (i.e. when the

trans-unit.source: view file is of the form ***ViewName**.Mobile.cshtml*).
trans-unit.target: view file is of the form ***ViewName**.Mobile.cshtml*).

trans-unit.source: You might want
trans-unit.target: You might want

trans-unit.source: to set `RequireConsistentDisplayMode` to `true` if your mobile layout
trans-unit.target: to set `RequireConsistentDisplayMode` to `true` if your mobile layout

trans-unit.source: doesn't work well with your non-mobile views.
trans-unit.target: doesn't work well with your non-mobile views.

trans-unit.target: The screenshot below shows

trans-unit.target: how the *Speakers* page renders when `RequireConsistentDisplayMode` is

trans-unit.source: set to `true` (without the string "(Mobile)" in the navigational bar at the top).
trans-unit.target: set to `true` (without the string "(Mobile)" in the navigational bar at the top).

trans-unit.target: ![][AllSpeakers_LayoutMobileOverridden]

trans-unit.source: You can disable consistent display mode in a specific view by setting
trans-unit.target: You can disable consistent display mode in a specific view by setting

trans-unit.source: `RequireConsistentDisplayMode` to `false` in the view file.
trans-unit.target: `RequireConsistentDisplayMode` to `false` in the view file.

trans-unit.target: However, it's a little bit

trans-unit.target: *Views\\Home\\SessionsTable.cshtml* and then replace the contents of the

trans-unit.source: file with the following code:
trans-unit.target: file with the following code:

trans-unit.source: The code does 3 things:
trans-unit.target: The code does 3 things:

trans-unit.source: uses the Bootstrap [custom linked list group][]
trans-unit.target: uses the Bootstrap [custom linked list group][]

trans-unit.source: to format the session information vertically, so that all this
trans-unit.target: to format the session information vertically, so that all this

trans-unit.source: information is readable on a mobile browser (using classes such as list-group-item-text)
trans-unit.target: information is readable on a mobile browser (using classes such as list-group-item-text)

trans-unit.source: applies the [grid system][] to the
trans-unit.target: applies the [grid system][] to the

trans-unit.source: layout, so that the session items flow horizontally in the desktop
trans-unit.target: layout, so that the session items flow horizontally in the desktop

trans-unit.source: browser and vertically in the mobile browser (using the col-md-4 class)
trans-unit.target: browser and vertically in the mobile browser (using the col-md-4 class)

trans-unit.source: uses the [responsive utilities][] to
trans-unit.target: uses the [responsive utilities][] to

trans-unit.source: hide the session tags when viewed in the mobile browser (using the hidden-xs class)
trans-unit.target: hide the session tags when viewed in the mobile browser (using the hidden-xs class)

trans-unit.source: You can also tap a title link to go to the respective session.
trans-unit.target: You can also tap a title link to go to the respective session.

trans-unit.target: The image
